unnormalised: Okay, so you know how everyone’s buzzing about AI and all that jazz? Well, in the Information Technology sector in India, it’s gone from buzz to a full-blown monsoon! I mean, seriously, every company, from startups in Koramangala to established giants in Gurgaon, is scrambling to integrate AI into… well, everything.

unnormalised: First off, let's talk coding. Forget banging your head against the wall trying to debug some ridiculously long piece of C++ code. Now we’ve got AI-powered code assistants like GitHub Copilot and Tabnine that are basically your nerdy coding buddies, except they don’t need chai breaks every 30 mins. They can suggest code snippets, identify bugs, and even write entire functions based on your comments. It's kinda scary, but mostly amazing.

unnormalised: Then there's cybersecurity. Remember the ransomware attack on AIIMS Delhi a while back? Nightmare, right? Now, AI is being used to detect and prevent these kinds of threats *before* they even happen. Think of it as an AI bodyguard for your entire IT infrastructure, constantly scanning for vulnerabilities and suspicious activity. Companies like Cisco are heavily invested in this, spending maybe $50M on R&D, I heard.

unnormalised: And don't even get me started on data analytics. We’re talking mountains of data, like seriously, terabytes upon terabytes. Previously, analysts were spending weeks, if not months, sifting through spreadsheets, trying to find some meaningful insights. Now, AI algorithms can do all that in a fraction of the time, uncovering hidden patterns and trends that humans would likely miss. Think predicting customer behavior or optimizing marketing campaigns – it's a game-changer.

unnormalised: But it’s not just about the tech itself. It’s also changing the way IT teams are structured and managed. We’re seeing a shift towards more agile, cross-functional teams that are able to adapt quickly to changing business needs. This means IT professionals need to be more versatile and have a broader skillset, including not just coding and networking, but also data analysis, AI ethics, and project management.

unnormalised: Of course, there are challenges. Data privacy is a huge concern, especially with the increasing amount of personal information being collected and processed. And then there's the ethical considerations of using AI, like ensuring that algorithms are fair and unbiased. We don’t want AI reinforcing existing inequalities, do we? So many seminars are held by NASSCOM focusing on AI ethics. They even had one on 22/07/2023 which I attended.

unnormalised: Another challenge is the skills gap. We need more people who have the expertise to build, deploy, and maintain AI systems. Universities like IIT are starting to offer specialized courses in AI and machine learning, but we need more initiatives like that. I heard there's a shortage of about 200K data scientists in India currently.
